job_title: Software Developer in New Orleans, LA
pros: Everyone was always very nice. I never had too much to do, it wasn't stressful at all. Very relaxed pace. Free college classes. Lots of paid holidays. They were extremely understanding and accommodating of life circumstances. I have nothing bad to say about anyone at Tulane, and I think for a lot of people it would be a dream job.
cons: The slow pace wasn't actually a pro for me. I was so bored. Went months without anything much to do, and not for lack of asking / looking for stuff to do. Over time this really messed with me, I felt bad for getting nothing done but had nothing to do. I never got bad feedback on the work I did do (which wasn't terribly interesting), but I felt bad all the time anyways because I knew I wasn't doing a good job by my own standards. I found it really depressing. So my advice is to be very aware of if you find not being busy to be a good thing or a bad thing before deciding whether to work here.

review_title: Part-time Adjunct Professor, Teaching 1 Class Per Semester
job_title: Adjunct Professor in New Orleans, LA
pros: Teaching for such a prestigious university looks great on a resume, and it's a great community to be associated with. Tulane is making actionable strides towards equity, diversity & inclusion for faculty, staff & students. During COVID, they are also requiring COVID testing every couple of weeks, even if you teach entirely remotely, leveraging the size & influence of their organization to keep the New Orleans community safer.
cons: As a part-time Adjunct Professor for the School of Professional Advancement, you are contracted to teach on a per-semester basis. You are paid a set amount for the entire semester, with payments distributed on a monthly basis throughout the semester. I'm afraid to actually try to calculate my true hourly rate, given all of the time that goes into class prep, grading and admin tasks. This job is definitely more about the love of teaching & the prestige of having Tulane University on my resume rather than the money.

job_title: Research Proposal Development Officer in New Orleans, LA
pros: The work is enjoyable for those interested in learning about a wide range of research topics, actively supporting others' research endeavors, and thrive on completing deadline-driven assignments. Co-workers were generous in sharing the workload of and collaborating on grant proposal assignments.
cons:
The "Good Ol' Boy" culture at Tulane University, which includes the implementation of “unconscious bias” in terms of both race and gender, can be effectively described as miasmatic, thinly veiled and insidious to those unfamiliar with navigating phenotypically stratified academic environments. 

What's worse is that negative behaviors (e.g. bullying, ridiculing by co-workers, sequestering accusations of discrimination, etc.) are consistently reinforced by individuals either complicit towards such actions or afraid to speak up in fear of retaliation. There have been several instances during my employment in which an employee would make disparaging comments toward another employee, or myself, during a meeting and not be adequately addressed. By anyone. 

My efforts to share resources on the psychological impacts of “othering and belonging” in the workplace were not met with accountability, empathy, dialogue, or actionable solutions. This was particularly frustrating when coupled with a suspicious uptick in “minority employee” hires in a presumed effort to capitalize on an optical illusion of diversity, equity and inclusion (Or in Tulane's eyes, $$$). Such modes of thought cannot be completely dismissed, especially given this school’s grisly history and track record of silencing the voices of the historically oppressed. My hunch is that Paul Tulane would "be awfully proud of dem good ol' boys and complicit gals."

In light of humor used to diffuse what may be aptly described as a traumatizing work experience, I encourage anyone reading this to exercise their discernment. Don't be afraid to ask "difficult" questions because they probe into the professional and overarching social climate of this institution. It could save a lot of time and energy, as well as preserve the mental health of individuals who identify as a minority in terms of race and/or gender. The straws that broke the camel’s back for me include 1) hearing a tenured black employee state “I wish my colleagues and students would treat me with respect” during a DEI meeting, 2) witnessing employees attempt to massage the definition of “minority” as to meet the statistical criteria for a federal research funding opportunity and 3) contempt towards the idea that grants promoting funding for minority health should collaborate with hospitals that have (...wait for it!) a high population of minority patients. What a beautifully straight-forward concept... One should not have to metaphorically pull teeth in order to ensure ethical practices outlined in the Hippocratic oath are properly implemented in all sectors. No place is perfect, but Tulane surely tested my patience.

Should one consider such position (especially transplants not familiar with the antiquated social hierarchy of "the Old South"), I’d advise to keep your moral compass in-tact and to not be afraid to speak out on what would externally be considered egregious behaviors by "leadership". Free speech that does not infringe upon the rights of others should be an exercised value within all educational systems. Academia should be a school of diverse thought, not a modern-day plantation for docile BIPOC or any other individual ensnared by indoctrination that creates fictitious hierarchies of worth amongst human lives. 

Tulane Univeristy, in my honest opinion, has a LONG way to go in order to create an atmosphere that indiscriminately and sustainably honors the birthright of every human: to feel safe, heard, valued, and mutually respected.

job_title: IT Manager in New Orleans, LA
pros:
-Free MBA
-Campus is pretty and nice to walk around when you need a break from how crappy your job is
cons:
-Salary is terrible, only reason anyone should work there is to get the free MBA. They were trying to get a web developer for 42k. In the private world, any decent web developer is 60k MINIMUM.
-On that subject, management routinely slashes salaries by 10% when someone quits, so if you're applying for a job, you're probably making substantially less than the person before you. They call it the cost of "knowledge transfer" but when pay is so terrible, it'll take 5+ years to match that.
-Don't expect any decent raises.
-There's so much bureaucracy and nonsense, don't expect to get anything accomplished. People don't want to change what they're doing. They'll hide behind their job descriptions and refuse to do anything new
-I don't know if the Tulane culture wears people down or if they join Tulane because they don't want to do much, but people here do the bare minimum. There are a few good people who actually want to do something right, but they usually leave or give up hope after a few years.
-Health benefits are pretty mediocre for a school that owns a hospital network

review_title: Graduate Student Experience at Dept. of Earth and Environmental Sciences
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in New Orleans, LA
pros: Brilliant department only if you are interested in sedimentary geology related to the Mississippi delta and river. Certain faculty members are very insightful, helpful and knowledgeable. Small size of department warrants in-depth interaction. Facilities and laboratories are limited but where available are well maintained.
cons:
Very niche expertise overall, only projects related to Mississippi delta system. Some professors are difficult to deal with and they tend to get influenced by views other people have about a student. Small department size limit multi-geoscience interactions.
Paperwork with office and the school is a tiresome job and the office-folks (finance, etc) tend to drop the ball now and then, for e.g. paycheck, reimbursement.

review_title: Great University and Student Body... not as great financial support.

review_title: Tulane University is part of New Orleans
job_title: Director in New Orleans, LA

job_title: Program Manager in New Orleans, LA
pros: Benefits include 2 weeks of vacation in your first year, 3 weeks for years 2-10 and 4 weeks after your 10th year. Additionally, you accrue sick time and Tulane closes for many holidays and between Christmas Eve & New Year's Day for Winter Break. Tulane contributes to a retirement account after your 2nd year and you don't even have to match to earn it (of course, it's smart if you do.) They have also instituted paid maternity leave (4 weeks, but it's a start.) Pay is around the national average.
cons: Bureaucracy can become tiresome.

job_title: in New Orleans, LA
pros: Excellent benefits--good health care, flexible time off, and free classes. You also have access to discounted membership to the Reily Recreation Center, and access to the university libraries. The work environment is generally positive and supportive, with very few high stress positions.
cons: There isn't a lot of room for advancement with a lot of the staff positions. The pay typically isn't as good as it is at universities in other cities, but this is probably the result of pay in New Orleans just being generally lower than other cities. Raises are given annually, but the percentage raise you get is pretty low.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Orleans, LA
pros: Tulane offers a lot of opportunities for students to work on campus, whether you have work study or not. If you're lucky, you can even get a job in your field doing research or working with a professor. There are job opportunities everywhere, from the recreational center to the library, that pay decent wages. Some even offer opportunities for advancement, which can be pretty rare for a student job.
cons: If you're a science major, there will be a lot of opportunities for you to work with professors. If you are anything other than a science major, it will be much harder to find a similar opportunity. They exist, there are just less of them.

review_title: My experience at Tulane was invaluable!!!

pros: The best thing about working for T The tuition waiver covers 6 hours per semester if you take classes and this is for both for employees and children. cons: Many of the department heads have no one to report to on a daily basis, except on paper. How are they to be held accountable if the department head never even meets the staff people that they work with. Who does that???

job_title: in New Orleans, LA
pros: Good vacation and sick time, offices are small so you can make an impact, you can take advantage of the interesting events around campus, tuition benefit is great.
cons: It is difficult to move around the company and networking is required to do so.  You must have a masters degree to move up in most departments although this is true of most educational organizations.

review_title: Great environment, poor treatment by some department managers, supervisors, and directors
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Orleans, LA
pros: Benefits are ok; paid holidays, sick & vacation time, health insurance (recently increased), dental discount, vision, contributes 8% of annual salary towards retirement (after 2years of employment...), but does not have a company matching program (employees can still contribute) FSA, life insurance, etc. Tuition waiver for two classes or six credit hours per semester which ever is equal or less than what the cap is. Some discounts on certain things campus wide; including laptop repair (which used to be free; students operate on it, but they don't take good care of it and could hardly ever figure out the problem), huge discount on software such as Microsoft Office. Other little perks here and there. One can browse the website for information. Can be a fun environment at times and there are always exciting events throughout the semester, but when the students are gone everything stops and the campus is pretty much empty.
cons:
In some departments there are incompetent and insensitive directors, managers & supervisors. they treat their employees like garbage and when they get upset or when they do not like you they begin to target you by harassing and micro-managing you & they are quick to tell you if you don't like it go work somewhere else. Majority of the employees are unhappy and are alway extremely stressed out. Its very oppressing, there's too much bureaucracy and favoritism. Hourly employees are overworked, underpaid and have no time for family and friends. You must work overtime every time they want you to and when you can not then your job is at risk. 
Managers gives evaluations that are very bias because if you are someone that does your job and stand up to the managers about their bullying of employees then they give you a bad review which goes to WFMO and you won't get a raise. The university makes you fill out an conflict-of-interest every year - not too bad except they hardly want you to do anything else. They want to own your time and no other work, not even your own company can have priority. Handbook says that nepotism is not allowed, however there is plenty of nepotism. Whenever you bring up an issue or even a suggestion it is dismissed, causes management to be offended, or they will patronage you like they care, but never take steps to make things better. Hopefully, employees will someday stand up against such horrible conditions and rise to flip the hierarchy system around. 


Please excuse any errors, I am typing from my iPad!

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Orleans, LA

job_title: in New Orleans, LA

review_title: The Beatings Will Continue Until Morale Improves

review_title: Your experience may vary, but mine has been wonderful.
job_title: Administrative Program Coordinator in New Orleans, LA
pros: Convenient location, beautiful campus, many resources and restaurants within walking distance. My coworkers and department are lovely, and I feel like a valued member of the staff. Great benefits, including paid parental leave and tuition waiver for yourself and dependents. Generally pleasant culture. Opportunity for lateral moves among different departments once you're here.
cons:
The parking situation is atrocious. I work at the front of campus, so I park in Cowen Circle. I have to pay hundreds of dollars (through pay deduction) for my parking pass. However, it's more like a "hunting permit." You have the pass, but you aren't actually guaranteed to find a spot, especially if you're looking around the front of campus. Spots in Cowen are often reserved with cones for "special events," and I have actually been called by parking services to move my vehicle, as they claimed there was a cone there but there wasn't. You either pay hundreds to MAYBE find a spot to park, or you don't pay and you have to walk miles to get to your office.

I have also heard that some departments at Tulane do not pay a living wage, or do not pay what employees deserve. I have heard of racial discrimination as well. These are not my own experiences, but I recognize that others have experienced this. As I said, your experience really varies depending on where you work.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Orleans, LA
pros:
Free tuition waiver for children and employees
Vacation 
Closed between Christmas and New Years

No opportunity for employees to take relevant courses during work day. Night courses did not apply to job.

Raises are a joke

I felt it is too intense to me and left the pot immediately.
